questions.question: In a community where consanguineous marriages are prevalent, a distant relative couple decide to get married. They later have a child who presents with symptoms of anaemia and requires regular blood transfusions. Further investigation reveals that the child has beta-thalassemia, a genetic disorder prevalent in the region. Which of the following symbols can be anticipated in this couple, which is a risk factor for this disease?

A couple seeks medical advice after their daughter presents with frequent nosebleeds and easy bruising. Lab investigations reveal prolonged bleeding time, prolonged aPTT, and a normal PT. A detailed history and a pedigree analysis were obtained, suspecting a genetic disorder. Based on the pedigree chart, what is this condition's most likely inheritance pattern?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) Autosomal dominant EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation of a female with frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, prolonged bleeding time & aPTT, and normal PT is suggestive of Von Willebrand disease. The pedigree chart shows a vertical transmission pattern with no skipping of generations and is suggestive of autosomal dominant inheritance. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern: The mode of transmission is vertical . An affected person has an affected parent. There is a 50% chance of the dominant trait being transmitted to offspring. Both males and females are equally affected. Examples of autosomal dominant disorders: Mnemonic Disease He H ereditary spherocytosis H ereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia H ereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC/Lynch syndrome) Has H untington’s disease H ypertrophic cardiomyopathy A A utosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease Very Von Willebrand disease V on Hippel Lindau syndrome Dominant D ystonia myotonica O steogenesis imperfecta M arfan’s syndrome I ntermittent

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of unsteady gait and frequent falls. Upon further inquiry, it is revealed that he has experienced progressive difficulty with coordination and balance over the past few years. His parents report a similar history in his older sister, who is now 15 years old. Interestingly, the parents are both asymptomatic, but the boy's maternal uncle was diagnosed with a similar condition in his late 20s. What is the most likely inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Autosomal recessive Explanation: The progressive difficulty with coordination and balance in both siblings, along with the maternal uncle's being affected, suggests Friedreich's ataxia (A repeat expansion of the trinucleotide GAA (guanine-adenine-adenine), typically in the gene's first intron, is the leading cause of this disease) a pattern consistent with autosomal recessive inheritance. In this scenario, both parents are likely carriers of a defective gene responsible for Friedreich's ataxia, and each sibling has inherited two copies of the defective gene , resulting in the development of this disorder. Autosomal recessive inheritance: Autosomal recessive disorders require both copies of the gene (one from each parent) to be affected for the condition to manifest. Horizontal transmission: The trait appears in siblings and parents are normal. History of consanguineous marriage: The parents are blood-related. Both the couple are carriers of abnormal genes. 25% chance of having an affected child (double dose of abnormal gene) in a carrier couple. Early age of onset and complete penetrance are common. Skipping of generations can be seen. Both males and females have an equal chance of getting affected. They include almost all inborn errors of metabolism. Examples of autosomal recessive disorders: Mnemonic Disease Pasta P henylketonuria A lkaptonuria S ickle cell anemia T halassemi a Fried F riedrich’s ataxia: Chawal C ystic fibrosis, C ongenital adrenal hyperplasia H emophilia C, H omocystinuria, H emochromatosis A lpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency W ilson’s disease A lbinism L ysosomal storage disorders, g l ycogen storage disorders DNA repair defects Big B loom syndrome Fax F anconi’s anemia A taxia telangiectasia X eroderma pigmentosum

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty walking. His parents report a family history of similar symptoms. A detailed history was obtained, and a pedigree analysis was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis and the inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D)Duchenne muscular dystrophy, X-linked recessive EXPLANATION: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease. X-linked recessive disorders: Females (XX) are carriers. Males are affected by the disease. Examples of X-linked recessive disorders: Mnemonic Diseases Wise Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome AB Hemophilia A, B Ocular albinism B Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia Becker muscular dystrophy C Chronic granulomatous disease Color blindness (Red-green) D Duchenne Muscular dystrophy E Lesch Nyhan syndrome F Fabry disease Fragile-X syndrome (X-linked recessive > X-linked recessive) G G-6-PD deficiency H Hunter’s disease

questions.question: In which of the following conditions can you see this pedigree chart?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Alport syndrome Explanation: An affected male will transmit the disease to all his daughters but not sons. An affected female can transmit the disease to both daughters and sons. Conditions with X-linked dominant inheritance: Rett syndrome. Alport syndrome (M/C inheritance pattern is X-linked dominant). Vitamin D-resistant rickets. Incontinentia pigmenti. Fabry’s disease (Option A) is X-linked recessive in inheritance. Albinism (Option B) is autosomal recessive in inheritance (ocular albinism: X-linked recessive) Reye syndrome (Option C) is a rare but serious condition primarily affecting children and teenagers, characterized by acute encephalopathy and liver dysfunction, often following a viral infection such as influenza or chickenpox, and strongly associated with the use of aspirin during these infections. Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Textbook of Anatomy, Volume 3, 6th edition, Page 500 Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th disease, Page 146

questions.question: Hairy pinna is associated with which type of Mendelian inheritance?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D)Y-linked inheritance EXPLANATION: Hairy pinna (hypertrichosis of pinna) is associated with Y-linked inheritance/ Holandric inheritance. Other examples: Webbed toes Porcupine man The image below shows a pedigree chart of Y-linked inheritance. Only males are affected, and transmission occurs only to the sons. Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th edition, Page no. 17,18

questions.question: A 25-year-old male has been complaining of painless, progressive central vision loss in both eyes over the past few months. He reports a family history of similar visual problems, with his maternal grandfather and maternal uncle experiencing sudden vision loss in their 20s. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes bilateral optic disc pallor and central scotomas on visual field testing. The patient denies any systemic symptoms or significant medical history. What is the inheritance pattern seen in this condition? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D) EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation, along with the family history of sudden vision loss in multiple maternal relatives, is highly suggestive of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) , a maternally inherited mitochondrial disorder affecting the optic nerves. Mitochondrial inheritance: A unique feature of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is maternal inheritance. This peculiarity exists because ova contain numerous mitochondria within their abundant cytoplasm, whereas spermatozoa contain few, if any. Hence the mtDNA complement of the zygote is derived entirely from the ovum. Thus, mothers transmit mtDNA to all their offspring , male and female. Daughters transmit the DNA to their further progeny. Properties: mtDNA encodes enzymes involved in oxidative phosphorylation , mutations affecting these genes exert their deleterious effects primarily on the organs most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation such as the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys. Each mitochondrion contains thousands of copies of mtDNA, and typically, deleterious mutations affect some, but not all, of these copies. Thus, tissues and individuals may harbor both wild-type and mutant mtDNA, which is known as heteroplasmy. A minimum number of mutant mtDNAs must be present in a cell or tissue before oxidative dysfunction causes disease. This is called the threshold effect. Mitochondria and their contained DNA are randomly distributed to the daughter cells during cell division. Thus when a cell containing normal and mutant mtDNA divides, the proportion of the normal and mutant mtDNA in daughter cells is extremely variable. Therefore the expression of disorders resulting from mutations in mtDNA is quite variable. Mitochondrial disorders: Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy. Mitochondrial myopathy. MELAS (Mitochondrial encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes). MERRF syndrome (Myoclonal Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibre). Kearns-Sayer syndrome. All generations of the family are affected in a vertical pattern with equal male and female involvement. Hence it shows autosomal dominant inheritance.(OPTION A) The mother has transmitted the defective gene to both her son and daughter. But, in the second generation, the father has transmitted the disease only to females. Hence it shows an X-linked dominant

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding gonadal mosaicism is true?

options.A: It is associated with autosomal recessive disorders.
options.B: It occurs due to a pre-zygotic mutation during early embryonic development.
options.C: It can be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.
options.D: It follows the laws of Mendelian inheritance.

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: C)It can be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta. EXPLANATION: The true statement regarding gonadal mosaicism is that it can be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta. GONADAL MOSAICISM/GERMLINE MOSAICISM The parent's sperm and ova are genotypically normal. On the fusion of normal sperm and normal ova, a normal zygote isformed. Post Zygotic mutation results in the disease. Gonadal mosaicism can be seen in: Osteogenesis imperfecta. (Option C) Tuberous sclerosis. Achondroplasia Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 180

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman has been newly diagnosed with breast cancer. Histopathological analysis of the tumour reveals invasive ductal carcinoma. Given the aggressive nature of her tumour, the oncologist wants to determine if the patient's cancer is HER2-positive. Which diagnostic method is most appropriate for detecting HER2/neu amplification in this patient?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) EXPLANATION: FISH uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. In the case of HER2 testing, FISH directly visualizes HER2 gene amplification by labelling the HER2 gene with a fluorescent probe. HER2 protein overexpression is virtually always caused by amplification of the region of chromosome 17q that contains the HER2 gene. The increase in HER2 gene copy number is detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization using a HER2-specific probe (red signal), which is typically co-hybridized to tumour cell nuclei with a second probe specific for the centromeric region of chromosome 17 (green signal), allowing the chromosome 17 copy number to be determined. FISH can be used for testing: Chromosomal translocations Deletions Amplifications FISH cannot detect point mutations. Immunohistochemistry (IHC): (Option A) IHC involves staining tissue samples with antibodies specific to HER2/neu protein. While widely used for HER2 testing, it does not directly measure gene amplification Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) (Option C ) PCR amplifies DNA sequences, including the HER2 gene, from tumour samples. It can detect gene amplification but It is not commonly used for HER2 testing in breast cancer patients. Western Blotting (Option D) Western blotting detects specific proteins in a sample but does not directly measure gene amplification. It is not commonly used for HER2 testing in breast cancer patients.

questions.question: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for prenatal screening due to advanced maternal age. She undergoes amniocentesis, and chromosome analysis is performed on the fetal cells to assess for chromosomal abnormalities . The results indicate Down syndrome. From the below chromosomal analysis, which of the following results is most likely associated with this case? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B EXPLANATION: B demonstrates the result as trisomy of chromosome 21, as along with two normal chromosomes, one extra chromosome is present, indicating trisomy 21 or Down’s syndrome as a diagnosis. TRISOMY 21: DOWN SYNDROME Karyotypes: Trisomy 21 type: 47,XX, +21 Translocation type: 46,XX,der(14;21)(q10;q10),+21 Mosaic type: 46,XX/47,XX, +21 Clinical Features of Down Syndrome Intellectual & Developmental Disabilities : Common, often with other neurological issues. Congenital Heart Defects (CHD) : Common defects include AVSD, VSD, ASD, Tetralogy of Fallot, and PDA. An echocardiogram is recommended for all newborns. Gastrointestinal Abnormalities : Includes duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, imperforate anus, GERD, chronic constipation, and celiac disease (5% prevalence). Hematologic Disorders : Neutrophilia, thrombocytopenia, polycythemia (resolves by 3 weeks), transient myeloproliferative disorder (10%), higher leukaemia risk. Neurologic Disorders : Hypotonia, seizures (5-13%, including infantile spasms), dementia, and early-onset Alzheimer's (50-70% by age 60). Endocrinological Disorders : Hypothyroidism, delayed puberty, sexual development issues, short stature. Musculoskeletal Disorders : Increased risk of joint dislocation, fractures, and bone mass loss. Visual Abnormalities : Cataracts, strabismus, refractive errors, nystagmus. Annual eye exams are recommended. ENT Disorders : Conductive hearing loss, chronic middle ear effusion, possible sensorineural hearing loss. The given image represents a normal karyotype. (Option A): The given image represents trisomy 18 – Edward syndrome (Option C) The given image represents two X chromosomes and one Y chromosome – Klinefelter’s syndrome (Option D)

questions.question: In a cytogenetics laboratory, a technician is tasked with preparing chromosomes obtained from a patient's blood sample for analysis under a light microscope. The patient has been experiencing unexplained developmental delays, and the physician suspects a potential chromosomal abnormality. To aid in the identification and analysis of individual chromosomes, which technique will the technician employ to produce distinct banding patterns?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) G-banding Explanation: G-banding involves staining chromosomes with Giemsa dye, which results in characteristic dark and light bands along the length of each chromosome. G-banding is the most widely used cytogenetic technique to visualize distinct banding patterns on chromosomes. It helps in: Identifying individual chromosomes Detecting structural abnormalities (e.g., deletions, duplications, translocations) Diagnosing chromosomal disorders linked to developmental delays It allows karyotyping with high accuracy. Each chromosome has a unique banding pattern , making it easier to detect abnormalities like trisomy, deletions, or rearrangements C-banding (Option B) selectively stains the centromeric regions Q-banding (Option C) also known as quinacrine staining, involves staining chromosomes with quinacrine mustard, which fluoresces under ultraviolet light R-banding (Option D) or reverse banding, is the reverse of G-banding . it produces light bands where G-banding shows dark, and vice versa. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no.164,165

questions.question: Which steps are NOT involved in the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) process?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) Ligation Explanation: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) involves three main steps: Denaturation, where the DNA double-strand separates into two single strands at 94 degrees Celsius. Annealing, where primers bind to the target DNA sequence at 54 degrees Celsius. Amplification, where DNA polymerase extends the primers to replicate the target sequence at 72 degrees Celsius. Ligation, which is the process of joining DNA fragments together, is not a step in PCR. Applications of PCR : Amplification of Gene Fragments : Serves as a fast alternative to cloning for gene fragment amplification. DNA Fragment Modification : Used to modify or engineer DNA fragments for further analysis. Detection of Pathogenic Microorganisms : Enables sensitive detection and genotyping of pathogens. DNA Analysis of Archaeological Specimens : Applied to study ancient DNA from archaeological remains. Mutation Detection : Identifies mutations associated with inherited diseases, cancer, and tissue typing. Forensic Analysis : Utilized for paternity testing, genetic marker analysis, and mapping hereditary traits. Species-Specific Amplification : Targets DNA segments between interspersed-repeat elements for species identification. Gene Expression Studies : Assists in studying gene expression and regulation. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no.181

questions.question: A 35-year-old female undergoes genetic testing due to a family history of Cystic Fibrosis. The test reveals a suspected deletion in the CFTR gene. Which technique is most suitable for confirming large deletions or duplications in the CFTR gene?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Multiplex Ligation Dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) Explanation: Multiplex Ligation Dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) is a molecular technique specifically designed for detecting copy number variations (CNVs), including large deletions or duplications in genes such as CFTR. It involves using multiple probes to target specific genomic regions, followed by ligation and amplification, allowing for the quantification and identification of CNVs. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. Page 181

questions.question: A researcher wants to analyze gene expression levels in a sample using a PCR technique that quantifies the amount of DNA produced after each amplification cycle. Which type of PCR is most suitable for this purpose?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Real-time PCR Explanation: Types of PCR: Type of PCR Characteristics Real-time PCR (qPCR) (Option A) Quantitative measurement of DNA amplification in real-time. Allows for gene expression analysis, viral load determination, and quantitative DNA/RNA analysis. Nested PCR (Option B) Two rounds of PCR amplification using two sets of primers. Improves specificity and sensitivity compared to conventional PCR. PCR (RT-PCR) (Option C) Enables gene expression analysis by amplifying RNA targets. Multiplex PCR (Option D) Simultaneous amplification of multiple DNA targets in a single reaction. Reduces time and cost by amplifying multiple targets together. Highly accurate for determining gene expression levels, viral load, and copy number variations. Digital PCR Divides the sample into thousands of individual reactions, allowing for absolute quantification of DNA targets. Provides high precision and sensitivity for rare target detection. Used in rare allele detection, copy number variation analysis, and precise quantification of nucleic acids. Hot Start PCR Minimizes non-specific amplification and primer-dimer formation by activating the DNA polymerase after an initial denaturation step. Prevents background noise and false-positive results. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 181

questions.question: Arrange the following steps of karyotyping in the correct sequence: Staining/Banding Sample collection Fixative Arrangement of chromosomes Arrest Interpretation
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 2, 5, 3, 1, 4, 6 Explanation: Karyotyping is the study of chromosomes. Sample collection: Patient type Sample type Pregnant woman Amniocentesis Chorionic villous sampling 10 year old boy Lymphocyte blood sample (preferred) Fibroblast skin sample 2.Arrest: It is carried out in metaphase using colchicine. 3.Fixative: Using Carnoy fixative (Methanol: Glacial acetic acid in 3:1 ratio ) 4.Staining/ Banding: Chromosome has dark (AT nucleotides rich) and light (CG nucleotides rich) bands. 5.Arrangement of Chromosomes: According to length in descending order. Shortest chromosome is chromosome 21. 6. Interpretations: Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome) Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) 47 XXY (Klinefelter syndrome)
